explanation:
Correct calculation: \(5 \times 5 \times 5 = 125\ \mathrm{cm}^3\)  
Student's calculation: \(5 \times 5 = 25\ \mathrm{cm}^3\)  

The student multiplied only two dimensions instead of three, treating the cube as a 2D shape (square) rather than 3D. This reflects a failure to recognize that volume requires three independent measurements (length × width × height), even when edges are equal. The error directly stems from applying area calculation logic (squaring) to a volumetric problem.  

While "mixes up cubing and squaring" is related, the root issue is the omission of the third dimension, as evidenced by the absence of a third factor in their calculation. Other misconceptions like general volume confusion are less specific to this error pattern.
